introduction.content: Spatially resolved transcriptomics (SRT) data captures the spatial organisation and heterogeneity of genes in tissues at high resolution, fundamentally transforming the way we study and understand biological processes. It has enabled the identification of key genes and pathways involved in intricate mechanisms underlying diverse biological processes and complex cellular phenomena [1] , [2] , [3] , [4] . While these new SRT technologies hold promise for producing new insights, they remain costly, preventing their direct adoption into routine clinical use at this stage. In contrast, haematoxylin-and-eosin-stained (H&E) histopathology images are more cost-effective and are routinely used in clinical practice. Thus, if we can leverage modern machine learning together with information from SRT technologies to predict in silico spatial profiles of gene expression values from paired histology images of the same tissue, we could enhance information gained from existing H&E images. This would facilitate large-scale examinations of spatial gene expression variations and lead to the potential discovery of biomarkers and therapeutic targets for complex diseases. To date, several approaches have been developed to predict in silico spatially resolved gene expression (SGE) patterns using H&E data alone (Fig. 1a , Supplementary Table 1 ). Among these methods, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Transformers are commonly selected architectures for extracting local and global 2D vision features around each sequenced spot from corresponding histology image patches. Some methods further implemented extra components, including super-resolution enhancement of SGE and Graph Neural Networks (GNN) to capture neighbourhood relationships between adjacent spots. Furthermore, an exemplar module had been used to guide predictions by inferring from the gene expression (GE) of the most similar exemplars. These learned features are then used to predict SGE that enables image-based screening for molecular biomarkers with spatial variation. As these methods were recently published in the last 3 years and are continuously evolving, their performance has not yet been comprehensively benchmarked. While there exist general reviews on various aspects of SRT analysis [5] , [6] , [7] , they have only surveyed and categorised methods predicting SGE from H&E without any benchmarking. Fig. 1: Overview of the benchmarking process and the key aspects of the evaluation. a Illustration of the machine learning task of predicting spatial gene expression from H&E images. b Overview of the evaluation categories used in the benchmarking of each method. Figure generated using Adobe Illustrator, with some graphics adapted from Adobe Stock under an Education License. Full size image Evaluation studies that are presented when proposing a new method are limited in nature and often not independent. Among the current literature, methods for predicting SGE from H&E have been mainly assessed and evaluated for their efficacy by their developers. Evidently, different evaluation frameworks have been used to assess the methods. For instance, ST-Net [8] , DeepSpaCE [9] , DeepPT [10] and TCGN [11] evaluated the performance of their models on external The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) [12] data to determine the generalisability of their models. Hist2ST [13] , EGNv1 [14] , EGNv2 [15] , TCGN and THItoGene [16] performed an ablation study to assess the contributions of different components of their deep-learning architecture. BrST-Net [17] conducted a comparison of 10 state-of-the-art CNN and transformer architectures to determine the effectiveness of the backbone models. iStar [18] demonstrated the application of its predictions by performing tissue region segmentation. Overall, there is no consistent and detailed evaluation framework comparing the performance of these approaches in predicting in silico SGE, due in part to the recent development of this field, limited data availability and the complexity of executing these methods. Consequently, we lack a comprehensive understanding of the performance, stability and the broader applicability of individual methods. Additionally, there is a lack of critical evaluation regarding how different spatial characteristics of H&E images can affect the accuracy of SGE predictions, especially on their impact on downstream analysis as well as potential clinical translation. To this end, we provide a benchmark and review of methods predicting SGE from H&E images. We compared the performance of eleven methods using 28 different metrics broadly grouped into five categories. These include metrics that focus on the evaluation of spatial and biological characteristics of genes that are predicted effectively. Metrics also include the impact of prediction performance on downstream applications. Given the ongoing development in predicting SGE from H&E providing exciting potential for clinical usage, our benchmark study provides an analysis of significant achievements of existing methods, demonstrating their practical impact. Importantly, we provide a vital assessment of the limitations and generalisability of their translational potential. Ultimately, we offer guidance for new users of these methods and highlight current challenges for developers aiming to advance methodologies. Furthermore, our study can serve as a valuable tool, facilitating the rapid and independent evaluation of future methods.

13.22: Hist2ST is used for elucidating molecular signatures of tissues.

15.1: Spatial transcriptomics is essential for understanding diseases.
15.2: Spatial transcriptomics is essential for developing novel treatments.
15.3: Spatial transcriptomics measures the gene expression of each fine-grained area in the tissue slide.
15.4: Spatial transcriptomics measures the gene expression with low throughput.
15.5: This paper proposes an exemplar guided graph network dubbed EGGN.
15.6: EGGN is proposed to accurately predict gene expression from each window of a tissue slide image.
15.7: EGGN is proposed to efficiently predict gene expression from each window of a tissue slide image.
15.8: Exemplar learning is applied to dynamically boost gene expression prediction.
15.9: Gene expression prediction is boosted from nearest/similar exemplars of a given tissue slide image window.
15.10: The framework has three main components connected in a sequence.
15.11: The first component is an extractor to structure a feature space for exemplar retrievals.
15.12: The second component is a graph construction strategy to connect windows and exemplars as a graph.
15.13: The third component is a graph convolutional network backbone to process window and exemplar features.
15.14: A graph exemplar bridging block is used to adaptively revise the window features using its exemplars.
15.15: The gene expression prediction task is completed with a simple attention-based prediction block.
15.16: Experiments on standard benchmark datasets indicate the superiority of the proposed approach.
15.17: The superiority of the proposed approach is indicated when compared with past state-of-the-art methods.
15.18: The code for the proposed work is released at https://github.com/Yan98/EGN.

16.1: Spatial transcriptomics unveils the complex dynamics of cell regulation.
16.2: Spatial transcriptomics unveils the complex dynamics of transcriptomes.
16.4: Predicting spatial gene expression from histological images via artificial intelligence offers a more affordable option than spatial transcriptomics.
16.5: Existing methods fall short in extracting deep-level information from pathological images when predicting spatial gene expression via artificial intelligence.
16.6: THItoGene is a hybrid neural network presented in this paper.
16.9: THItoGene adaptively senses potential molecular signals in histological images.
16.10: THItoGene explores the relationship between high-resolution pathology image phenotypes and regulation of gene expression.
16.11: A comprehensive benchmark evaluation was conducted using datasets from human breast cancer and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.
16.12: The comprehensive benchmark evaluation demonstrated the superior performance of THItoGene in spatial gene expression prediction.
16.13: THItoGene has demonstrated its capacity to decipher the spatial context within specific tissue regions.
16.14: THItoGene has demonstrated its capacity to decipher enrichment signals within specific tissue regions.
16.15: THItoGene can be freely accessed at https://github.com/yrjia1015/THItoGene.

viewpoints: Hist2ST performed an ablation study to assess the contributions of different components of its deep-learning architecture.
EGNv1 performed an ablation study to assess the contributions of different components of its deep-learning architecture.
EGNv2 performed an ablation study to assess the contributions of different components of its deep-learning architecture.
TCGN performed an ablation study to assess the contributions of different components of its deep-learning architecture.

sentences.sentence: BrST-Net [17] conducted a comparison of 10 state-of-the-art CNN and transformer architectures to determine the effectiveness of the backbone models.

17.1: Tumour heterogeneity in breast cancer poses challenges in predicting the outcome of breast cancer.
17.2: Tumour heterogeneity in breast cancer poses challenges in predicting the response to therapy in breast cancer.
17.3: Spatial transcriptomics technologies may address the challenges posed by tumour heterogeneity in breast cancer.
17.4: Spatial transcriptomics technologies provide a wealth of information about gene expression at the cell level.
17.6: The expense of spatial transcriptomics technologies hinders their use in large-scale clinical oncology studies.
17.7: Predicting gene expression from hematoxylin and eosin stained histology images provides a more affordable alternative to spatial transcriptomics technologies for large-scale clinical oncology studies.
17.8: BrST-Net is a deep learning framework for predicting gene expression from histopathology images.
17.9: BrST-Net uses spatial transcriptomics data for predicting gene expression from histopathology images.
17.10: Four distinct state-of-the-art deep learning architectures were trained and evaluated using BrST-Net.
17.11: The four deep learning architectures include ResNet101, Inception-v3, EfficientNet (with six different variants), and vision transformer (with two different variants).
17.12: The deep learning architectures were trained and evaluated without utilizing pretrained weights for the prediction of 250 genes.
17.13: An auxiliary network was introduced into the BrST-Net framework to enhance the generalisation performance of the main network.
17.14: The methodology involving BrST-Net outperforms previous studies.
17.15: The methodology identified 237 genes with positive correlation.
17.16: The methodology identified 24 genes with a median correlation coefficient greater than 0.50.
17.17: This improvement is notable compared to previous studies.
17.18: Previous studies could only predict 102 genes with positive correlation.
17.19: The highest correlation values in previous studies ranged from 0.29 to 0.34.

viewpoints: BrST-Net conducted a comparison of 10 state-of-the-art CNN architectures to determine the effectiveness of the backbone models.
BrST-Net conducted a comparison of 10 state-of-the-art transformer architectures to determine the effectiveness of the backbone models.

sentences.sentence: iStar [18] demonstrated the application of its predictions by performing tissue region segmentation.

18.1: Spatial transcriptomics (ST) has demonstrated enormous potential for generating intricate molecular maps of cells.
18.2: Spatial transcriptomics (ST) is used within tissues.
18.3: iStar is a method based on hierarchical image feature extraction.
18.4: iStar integrates spatial transcriptomics (ST) data and high-resolution histology images.
18.5: iStar predicts spatial gene expression with super-resolution.
18.6: iStar enhances gene expression resolution to near-single-cell levels in spatial transcriptomics (ST).
18.7: iStar enables gene expression prediction in tissue sections where only histology images are available.

viewpoints: iStar demonstrated the application of its predictions by performing tissue region segmentation.

sentences.sentence: Overall, there is no consistent and detailed evaluation framework comparing the performance of these approaches in predicting in silico SGE, due in part to the recent development of this field, limited data availability and the complexity of executing these methods.
viewpoints: Overall, there is no consistent evaluation framework comparing the performance of approaches predicting in silico spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
Overall, there is no detailed evaluation framework comparing the performance of approaches predicting in silico spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The lack of a consistent and detailed evaluation framework is due in part to the recent development of the field of predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
Limited data availability contributes to the lack of a consistent and detailed evaluation framework for predicting in silico spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The complexity of executing these methods contributes to the lack of a consistent and detailed evaluation framework for predicting in silico spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).

sentences.sentence: Consequently, we lack a comprehensive understanding of the performance, stability and the broader applicability of individual methods.
viewpoints: We lack a comprehensive understanding of the performance of individual methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
We lack a comprehensive understanding of the stability of individual methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
We lack a comprehensive understanding of the broader applicability of individual methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).

sentences.sentence: Additionally, there is a lack of critical evaluation regarding how different spatial characteristics of H&E images can affect the accuracy of SGE predictions, especially on their impact on downstream analysis as well as potential clinical translation.
viewpoints: There is a lack of critical evaluation regarding how different spatial characteristics of haematoxylin-and-eosin-stained (H&E) images can affect the accuracy of spatially resolved gene expression (SGE) predictions.
There is a lack of critical evaluation on the impact of different spatial characteristics of H&E images on downstream analysis.
There is a lack of critical evaluation on the potential clinical translation of different spatial characteristics of H&E image data on spatially resolved gene expression (SGE) predictions.

sentences.sentence: To this end, we provide a benchmark and review of methods predicting SGE from H&E images.
viewpoints: The study provides a benchmark and review of methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE) from H&E images.

sentences.sentence: We compared the performance of eleven methods using 28 different metrics broadly grouped into five categories.
viewpoints: The study compared the performance of eleven methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The comparison used 28 different metrics broadly grouped into five categories.

sentences.sentence: These include metrics that focus on the evaluation of spatial and biological characteristics of genes that are predicted effectively.
viewpoints: The metrics include those that focus on the evaluation of spatial characteristics of genes that are predicted effectively.
The metrics include those that focus on the evaluation of biological characteristics of genes that are predicted effectively.

sentences.sentence: Metrics also include the impact of prediction performance on downstream applications.
viewpoints: The metrics also include the impact of prediction performance on downstream applications.

sentences.sentence: Given the ongoing development in predicting SGE from H&E providing exciting potential for clinical usage, our benchmark study provides an analysis of significant achievements of existing methods, demonstrating their practical impact.
viewpoints: The ongoing development in predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE) from H&E provides exciting potential for clinical usage.
The benchmark study provides an analysis of significant achievements of existing methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The analysis demonstrates the practical impact of existing methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).

sentences.sentence: Importantly, we provide a vital assessment of the limitations and generalisability of their translational potential.
viewpoints: The study provides a vital assessment of the limitations of existing methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The study provides a vital assessment of the generalisability of the translational potential of existing methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).

sentences.sentence: Ultimately, we offer guidance for new users of these methods and highlight current challenges for developers aiming to advance methodologies.
viewpoints: The study offers guidance for new users of methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The study highlights current challenges for developers aiming to advance methodologies for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).

sentences.sentence: Furthermore, our study can serve as a valuable tool, facilitating the rapid and independent evaluation of future methods.
viewpoints: The study can serve as a valuable tool for facilitating the rapid evaluation of future methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
The study can serve as a valuable tool for facilitating the independent evaluation of future methods for predicting spatially resolved gene expression (SGE).
